thread.title: Community turns out for blood drive supporting Aliquippa football player
thread.title_full: Community turns out for blood drive supporting Aliquippa football player

author: Kirstin Kennedy kkennedy@timesonline.com
title: Community turns out for blood drive supporting Aliquippa football player
text:
0 
BEAVER -- Friends, family members, rival high schools, they're all saying it: #24strong. 
The sentiment supports Aliquippa High School football player DiMantae Bronaugh who is spending his senior year on the sidelines, battling a form of leukemia. 
To raise awareness for DiMantae and patients like him, Central Blood Bank and members of his family hosted a community blood drive Tuesday at Beaver United Methodist Church in Beaver. 
DiMantae's aunt and caregiver, Anita Gordon, said her nephew has used donated blood throughout his treatment, which requires transfusions. Gordon said she was excited at the opportunity to help replenish the local supply. 
Tamara Kilgore, marketing communications manager for the Institute for Transfusion Medicine, helped to organize the event with Central Blood Bank. She reached out to the Aliquippa School District and to Gordon to plan the drive. 
While the blood collected Tuesday won't go directly to DiMantae, Kilgore said it will go to a variety of patients in need across western Pennsylvania. 
DiMantae and some of his cousins attended the blood drive. While DiMantae couldn't donate blood, he thanked his supporters. He's excited to play football next year when he retakes his senior year, and said he's feeling well. 
At first, the diagnosis rocked him, he said. But as he saw how much the community supported and prayed for him, he filled with hope. 
According to Gordon, DiMantae's doctors are pleased with his test results, and told her his cancer is in remission. He will still need to undergo his scheduled treatments. 
DiMantae has been dedicated to supporting the Aliquippa football team, and said he's gone to all the games with the team. Similarily, the community has been supportive of him. Kilgore said the turn out for the blood drive was strong. 
From behind a shy smile, DiMantae said if he could like his supporters with one thing, it would be to say thank you. Tags
